unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: One-Proportion Z-Test
question_text:
The landlord of a $16$-story apartment building is curious if his tenants are happy with the current temperature in the building.
He surveys the first floor and finds that $26$ out of the $40$ tenants are happy with the current temperature. Suppose the landlord wanted to perform a one-proportion z-test.
Which of the conditions are violated for this procedure?

choices.text: The population is not at least $10$ times the sample.
The sampling distribution is not approximately normal.
The expected counts are not more than $5$.
The data does not come from an SRS.

solution:
Choice 'A' is incorrect; assuming the floors are relatively the same size, by surveying one of the $16$ floors, the population should be at least $10$ times the sample.

Choice 'B' is incorrect; the sampling distribution will be approximately normal since np and n ($1$-p) are both more than $10$ (or $5$).

Choice 'C' is incorrect; expected counts are part of chi-squared conditions, but not for a one-proportion Z-test.

Choice 'D' is incorrect; sample size for proportions does not matter as long as np and n ($1$-p) are both more than $10$ (or $5$).

Choice 'E' is correct; this is not an SRS. It is possible that tenants on the first floor have different feelings about the buildingâ€™s temperature than do tenants in the rest of the building.
